content: How can I help you today?

I'm having a lot of trouble sleeping lately. My mind just won't stop racing at night. There’s so much stress with work and money, and I’m scared it’s all piling up too much. My partner suggested I try talking to someone, so here I am.

Thank you for sharing what’s going on—it sounds like you’re carrying a heavy load right now with work, finances, and trying to manage everything. It can be so difficult when stress is affecting your sleep and leaving you feeling stuck. What’s it been like for you to handle all of this lately?

It’s been overwhelming, honestly. I’m constantly worried about losing my job because things aren’t going great at work, and if that happens, I don’t know how I’d take care of my family. It’s like this constant loop in my head at night, and even though I know looking at my phone makes it worse, I do it anyway just to distract myself. It’s exhausting.

That sounds incredibly hard—feeling that weight of responsibility for your family and the worry about work while trying to juggle everything. It makes sense that you’d turn to distractions like your phone, even if it doesn’t help in the long run, because you're just trying to find some relief. How do you feel about the stress and its impact on your ability to take care of yourself during all of this?

Honestly, I feel like I’ve been neglecting myself a lot. I don’t really have the energy or time to focus on me because I’m so worried about everything else—providing for my family, being a good parent, keeping my job. It feels selfish to spend time on myself when there’s so much to fix. But at the same time, I know I’m running myself into the ground.

It’s a tough spot to be in, balancing the responsibilities and care you have for your family while feeling like your own well-being is slipping through the cracks. It sounds like part of you acknowledges the importance of taking care of yourself, but another part feels guilty about it—like self-care might take away from everything else you're working so hard to manage. How do you feel about that tug-of-war between caring for yourself and focusing on everything else?

I know I can’t pour from an empty cup, but it’s so hard to believe that taking time for myself won’t make things worse. If I don’t keep pushing and focusing on everything else, I’m scared it’ll all fall apart. At the same time, I know that burning myself out won’t help anyone in the long run. It’s frustrating—I just don’t know how to find that balance.

It makes sense to feel frustrated—you’re trying to hold everything together, but you’re also aware that pushing yourself too far could ultimately make things harder. It sounds like you deeply care about your family and responsibilities, but you're also recognizing that something has to shift to avoid burnout. What do you think would need to happen for you to start finding that balance you're looking for?

I don’t really know. I guess I’d need to figure out a way to slow my thoughts down at night and stop feeling like everything depends on me all the time. But that feels impossible right now with everything that’s going on.

It sounds like you’re searching for a way to find some peace in your busy mind and to ease the pressure you’ve been carrying alone. Feeling like everything depends on you can be overwhelming, especially when the stress seems constant. Even though it feels impossible right now, you’ve recognized these things as important steps toward feeling better. What would it mean to you if you could slow things down and take off some of that weight?

I think it would mean a lot. If I could get to a place where my mind feels quieter and I’m not so weighed down, maybe I’d have more energy and patience to keep up with work, my kids, and everything else. It feels so far off, though, like I don’t even know where to start to get there.

That longing for a quieter, more manageable place feels really real—where you could have the energy and patience to show up for the people and responsibilities you care about so much. Even though it feels far off, you’re already exploring what could bring you closer to it just by sharing your feelings here. What’s one small step, no matter how small, that you think could help move you toward that?

Maybe I could start by putting my phone away earlier at night. I know it just makes things worse, but it’s so hard to not reach for it when my mind’s spinning. It’s a small thing, and I’m not even totally sure if I can stick to it, but I guess it’d be a place to start.

That’s a thoughtful and practical place to start—setting your phone aside earlier could give your mind a little more space to wind down before bed. Even though you’re unsure if you can stick to it, you’re showing a willingness to try, and that’s a meaningful step forward. What might help you stay consistent with it?

Maybe setting a reminder for myself or even leaving my phone in another room could help. I just worry that if I can’t distract myself with my phone, my thoughts are going to get even louder. But I guess I won’t know until I try.

Leaving your phone in another room and setting a reminder are great ideas—those small actions could create some distance between you and the distractions at night. It’s understandable to worry that giving up your phone might make your thoughts feel louder, and it’s brave of you to consider trying anyway. What else could help bring some calm or comfort in those moments when your thoughts start to feel overwhelming?

Maybe I could try some breathing exercises or listen to calming music instead. I’ve heard people say those things help, but I’ve never really tried them myself. I’m not sure if they’d work, but it might be better than just staring at my phone.

Breathing exercises or calming music sound like gentle, supportive alternatives to help you quiet your mind, especially if it feels overwhelming without the distraction of your phone. It's encouraging that you're open to exploring different options, even if you're unsure how they'll work for you right now. Would you like to talk about how you might give these ideas a try, or is there something else you’d like to explore?

Honestly, I think I have enough to start with for now. Thank you for listening and helping me think through some of this. I’ll try to take those small steps and see how it goes. I appreciate your time.
